__params = {'default_color': <param.Color object>, 'evap_const': <param.Magnitude object>, 'fixed_max': <param.Boolean object>, 'gaussian_sigma': <param.NumericTuple object>, 'grid_dims': <larvaworld.lib.param.custom.PositiveIntegerRange object>, 'initial_value': <param.Number object>, 'name': <param.parameterized.String object>, 'odorscape': <param.Selector object>, 'selected': <param.Boolean object>, 'unique_id': <param.parameterized.String object>, 'visible': <param.Boolean object>}ÔÉÅ
_param = <param.parameterized.Parameters object>ÔÉÅ
_parameters_state = {'BATCH_WATCH': False, 'TRIGGER': False, 'events': [], 'watchers': []}ÔÉÅ
evap_const = 0.9ÔÉÅ
gaussian_sigma = (0.95, 0.95)ÔÉÅ

A typical diffusion coefficient for a molecule in the gas phase is in the range of 10-6 to 10-5 m2/sigma

Yes, it does that automatically based on the sigma and truncate parameters. Indeed, the function gaussian_filter is implemented by applying multiples 1D gaussian filters (you can see that here). This function uses gaussian_filter1d which generate itself the kernel using _gaussian_kernel1d with a radius of int(truncate * sigma + 0.5).

Doing the math, sigma ends up reeeeally small

name = 'DiffusionValueLayer'ÔÉÅ
odorscape = 'Diffusion'ÔÉÅ

__params = {'default_color': <param.Color object>, 'fixed_max': <param.Boolean object>, 'grid_dims': <larvaworld.lib.param.custom.PositiveIntegerRange object>, 'initial_value': <param.Number object>, 'name': <param.parameterized.String object>, 'selected': <param.Boolean object>, 'unique_id': <param.parameterized.String object>, 'visible': <param.Boolean object>}ÔÉÅ

draw_isocontours(v)[source]ÔÉÅ
generate_thermoscape()[source]ÔÉÅ

size is the length of the square arena in mm. rezo is the resolution with 1 being a mm, 0.1 being a 10th of a mm. spread is the spread put into the multivariate_normal function. pTem is the plate Temp i.e. the standard temperature of the plate - default is 22ÀöC. origins are the coordinate locations on the size x size plate of the heat or cold sources. type: list tempDiff needs to be a list the same length as origins, and determines if that source will be cold or hot and by how much. In other words a <ptemp> of 22 and a <origins> of [[10,20], [30,40]] and <tempDiff> of [8,-8] would make a temperature source at [10,20] that is ~30ÀöC and a source at [30,40] that is ~14ÀöC. The mean is taken where the temperatures of multiple sources overlap.

get_grid()[source]ÔÉÅ
get_thermo_value(pos)[source]ÔÉÅ
name = 'ThermoScape'ÔÉÅ
unique_id = 'ThermoScape'ÔÉÅ
